characters: AT THE BACK OF THE GARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a very lovely street in a very nice neighborhood, Tom Sykes, THE HIDER, is out for a walk.  The Hider is a man who blends in well with his surroundings.  A good-looking man in his thirties.  To look at him, you wouldn't know there was anything wrong... The Hider walks with such strange grace that he could be on a conveyor belt, a variety of neighborhood houses passing him by, one style after another. Sunlight and shadow play over the Hider's face as he walk filtered through the lush trees and greenery all around. Then the hedge he's walking past ends and the next house makes him stop.  Because it isn't a house yet.  It's a half-house.  A house under reconstruction.  Part built, part torn down, part finished, part matchstick frame.  An evolving house, with a swarm of workmen all over it, hammering, sawing, drilling. The Hider stands and watches awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The workmen have gone.  The Hider enters the house from t back where it's all completely open without doors or windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider explores in the waning light.  There are buildi materials about.  He runs his hand over a pile of bricks. He looks at some wooden boards and planks leaning against a wall.  WIND HOWLS through the dark house. He tries the tap on a newly installed sink.  Water gushes out. Where the main stairway will be is now only a ladder.  Th Hider climbs it to the next floor.  There are a number of rooms; a hallway to more rooms.  On a worktable are some plans and blueprints.  The Hider looks at them. Behind a door is a narrow little stairway.  The Hider goe up it to --

dialogues.speaker: THE ATTIC
dialogues.text: A fairly large attic, with a small window at one end.  Th attic is a part of the house that has remained pretty muc untouched. The Hider looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trap door is opened.  The Hider climbs out from the attic.  He surveys the scene from up here.  Below in the backyard there's an empty swimming pool, a partially completed patio, piles of dirt. Because the house itself has many curves and corners and levels, so does the roof.  The Hider jumps down to anothe section and teeters for a moment where there's a gaping hole (where the skylight will be).  He catches himself. The hole goes right through the house all the way to the ground floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider drops back in from the roof.  He goes to the small window and looks out over the front street and neighborhood.  The Hider feels tired.  He lies down on th attic floor and curls up. MAIN TITLES BEGIN.

dialogues.speaker: EXT./INT. MAIN TITLE SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: In which we SEE the gradual progress of the house as it grows toward completion -- juxtaposed with the activities of the Hider as he follows his own secret agenda: We SEE builders carefully fit a big skylight into place over that hole in the roof. We SEE how the Hider spends his days -- in a library, studying diagrams in a book on Home Improvements. We SEE him in the house at night, up in the attic, workin on the floor in some way, hunched so we can't see.  He's draped a black cloth over the attic window and is surrounded by candles. We SEE the house taking shape.  Carpenters finishing a staircase. We SEE the Hider eating alone in a simple cafeteria. We SEE the back of the house at night.  The Hider appears over the edge of the roof, rappelling down on a rope, making little toeholds in the wall as he goes.  CHINK-CHI with a small hammer, the SOUND MUFFLED by cloth.  The hou is quite private from the view of its neighbors, and the section of wall the Hider has chosen for his secret ladde is further shadowed by being an indented corner. We SEE plumbers at work and painters arrive. We SEE the Hider cashing his disability insurance check a a check-cashing place. We SEE the house further along.  Painters painting. Electricians wiring.  Landscape gardeners planting. We SEE the Hider returning to the house at night, emergin out of shadows.  He goes to his special corner, looking around -- and starts climbing.  His hands and shoes findi the chinks in the wall only he knows are there.  In LONG SHOT, if we see the figure climbing fly-like up the side of the house at all, it's only because we know he's there We SEE locksmiths installing locks on doors.  Not that it will do any good now. We SEE the Hider drop silently to the ground at night. Newly planted vines help hide his descent even more and cause natural shadows to move on the side of the house in the breeze of the night.  The Hider walks down into the empty pool.  He stands in the middle of it.  There's a fu moon.  The Hider spreads his arms as if to float backward SPLASH!  We SEE the Hider backstroking off one end of a long swimming pool.  He rolls in the water and swims to t other end where he climbs out.  The Hider is strong and powerfully built.  He retrieves a towel from a bench.  Th towel says "YMCA." We SEE the Hider at his YMCA locker, after having a showe Inside is everything he owns in the world.  The locker is packed with stuff. We SEE the house nearing completion.  Two men with clipboards walk around, checking final details. They go up to the attic.  Everything looks fine.  They go back down, closing the attic stairway door. We SEE the Hider at a booth in a coffee shop, sketching a diagram in a notebook while he eats. We SEE the house is done.  And here the MAIN TITLES PAUSE Because we are almost at the end of our set-up now.  Just one more important job to be taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's RAINING.  The house is all finished.  There are no more trucks parked on the street.  No more rubble in the driveway.  Nothing abnormal to set the house apart from a others on the street.  The house is still and peaceful in the rain and part of the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swimming pool has now been filled with water.  And RAINDROPS pound into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rooms are stark and empty.  White walls.  Shiny wood floors.  Light reflected off their smooth surfaces.  Comi through the bare windowpanes.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTION HALL
dialogues.text: Here by the solid front door, the house is an invitation. The hallway leading deeper in.  Doors to rooms.  The stairway to the next landing.  The skylight over all, RAI spattering up there on the thick glass. The only other NOISE, indistinct, is coming from the atti

dialogues.speaker: THE ATTIC
dialogues.text: The Hider has the house to himself now.  He's finishing h wall -- a false wall at the far end of the attic.  The re wall goes straight for a while then juts off at an angle to form a sort of alcove.  The Hider has bricked off this alcove, giving the illusion of one straight wall running the length of the attic.

dialogues.speaker: THE ATTIC
dialogues.text: The rain has stopped.  Now the Hider is plastering his wall.

dialogues.speaker: THE ATTIC
dialogues.text: The Hider is taking a breather.  He stands looking out of the small attic window as he eats a sandwich.  To the right, he sees a NASTY NEIGHBOR yell at some Kids who've come to retrieve their ball from his property.  The Nasty Neighbor kicks the ball away as hard as he can.  On the left, a car pulls into the driveway of the other neighboring house.  A mother (the NICE NEIGHBOR) bringing her kids home from school -- a Boy and a Girl.  Another b comes by on a bike, pausing to talk to the first Boy.  At a house across the street, the Hider hears a DOOR SHUT an sees a Cleaning Woman in a white uniform walk away along a path.

dialogues.speaker: THE ATTIC
dialogues.text: The Hider stands back to look over his handiwork.  The false wall is now indistinguishable from the real wall. Such a good job that one wonders why the Hider built it, why he's cut off the extra space behind it, apparently without access... ... but wait.  He's made a secret panel in the floor.  By pushing down in a certain way then sliding away a section of floorboard, a hole is revealed, cut large enough to fi him like a coffin.  He lies in it, covering himself up wi the sliding floorboard again, which CLICKS neatly back in place, and --

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE FALSE WALL
dialogues.text: -- as he rolls under the wall, coming up out of a similar trap on the other side.  He slides a floorboard cover int place over it.  He pulls down a foam mattress that he's c to size and blankets from where they've been hooked up. He props up two pillows in place and sits against the fro wall beyond which is the street.  He looks over his shoulder, pulling the lever of a second vent he's install in this wall for air and to enable him to look out over t street.  Across the way, a mailman delivers mail to house A woman walking her dog says hello to the mailman.  The Hider looks forward again.  He's made a shelf or two for himself.  There are a few books, some snacks, a Thermos a plastic bottles of water.  He has a few other things.  He has a lantern and a flashlight. The space here is big enough for him to lie down with his arms at his sides, or to stand comfortably.  Like a monk in his cell, it's a room of his own.

dialogues.speaker: THE ATTIC
dialogues.text: Silent.  Empty.  The Hider behind the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and one last thing... a "FOR SALE" sign out in front. MAIN TITLES END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning in the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REAL-ESTATE LADY comes in with a Yuppie Couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and it's been done up so beautifully, you're lucky to be the first people to look at it. It's my personal favorite of all of our homes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step into the light of the reception area, their hea turning up instinctively to the skylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider looks tense.  And displeased.  His privacy has been disturbed.  There are strangers in his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOOTSTEPS approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- then there's the kitchen, which has been entirely remodelled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes in and we SEE that it's a SECOND REAL-ESTATE LADY -- with an Older Couple this time. The wife goes to the sink and turns the tap.  She jumps back in fright as it SPITS violently and no water comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going over) That's strange.  I what could be wrong here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Couple have tried a tap, and this time the faucet has burst -- exploding water at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch!  A Single Man scratches his arm on a nasty splinter as he goes through a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he comes out, the door now comes unhinged, falling on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Men are led upstairs.  Along the way, one of them notices a large patch of dampness on the wall and brings it to the attention of his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spreadeagled on the roof as he peeks down through the skylight... the Hider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Black Couple are being taken through the house.  Sudden the wife notices something on the floor as they pass -- a "Roach Motel."  She and her husband look at each other distastefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider looks over a display of meat.  He selects a steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider puts the steak away -- underneath the floor of a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Fat Couple are sniffing the air as they follow a REAL-ESTATE MAN.  The Real-Estate Man opens the door to a room -- and a cascade of flies swarms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fat Couple hurry out, handkerchiefs over their noses, chased by the upset Real-Estate Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- in all new houses there are certain kinks to be ironed out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE UP to that vent in the wall at the very top of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches the Fat Couple leaving.  His expression says: "Yeah, that's it, go away, go away, you awful people."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car approaches the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider is lying on the floor in a patch of sunlight. When he hears the CAR PARK and DOORS OPEN, he stands up i one quick movement and goes to the side of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The original Real-Estate Lady has come out of the car. While from the other side of the car emerges --

dialogues.speaker: JULIE DREYER
dialogues.text: A beautiful woman.  She gets out of the car with an extraordinary grace. She smooths her skirt with one light brush of her hand. She turns to look at the house, afternoon sunlight fallin on one side of her face.

dialogues.speaker: THE HIDER
dialogues.text: His face moving closer to the window, though keeping to t side in shadow.

dialogues.speaker: THE HIDER'S FACE
dialogues.text: A look we haven't seen before.  A look of fascination. He's smitten.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE DREYER
dialogues.text: Walking toward the house now, glancing gently from side t side, almost gliding.

dialogues.speaker: THE HIDER
dialogues.text: steps back from the window, instinctively neatening his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens and the Real-Estate Lady and Julie come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been on the market a while, hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not very long.  There have been a couple of bids already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it caught my eye when it was in a higher price bracket in the listings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, well, you know, when developers remodel a house they often overestimate their costs at first.  It's not like it's been marked down or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sly look) Just reduced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concedes with a shrug) Sometimes they prefer a quicker return on their investment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a terrific entrance hall, What a welcoming feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie steps on a floorboard that CREAKS, but it doesn't seem to bother her.  It's clear her first impressions of the house are very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie and the Real-Estate Lady come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see that there's really much more space than the average three bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, space!  -- You said the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How large is your brood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two -- three if you count the husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must always count the husband. By my count there've been... four. But I still live in hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is looking around, still liking what she sees.  She goes into the room the Hider was in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he's not here now.  Julie walks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Phil wasn't sure he wanted us to be this far outside the city.  But we have friends around here and something told me I should take a look at this house. I want to be somewhere surrounded by green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The window the Hider was at has been opened, the branch of a tree swaying outside it, and Julie takes a breath, the air fresh and sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... I just had a feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks around the room, almost a waltz in beauty.  She comes to the closet.  She opens the door and looks in, le and right.  It's quite empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the front bedroom that Julie is in.  The Hider is crouched on the floor, a look of contentment on his face. his cheek against the wood like a caress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider is sitting in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the new place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great.  It's clean and airy and quiet -- there are trees and flowers.  There's still some fixing up I have to do, but it's coming along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the rent is okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's nothing.  No problem. I was really lucky to find this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then.  That's important, isn't it?  -- For you to be in an "up" environment.  I'm saying you should literally take that as your base, do you know what I mean? It's something positive that you've accomplished -- even if you were forced by circumstance -- something for you to build upon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about work?  Have you had any more thoughts about what you'd like to be doing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've been doing a little independent contracting, some carpentry here and there, y'know, do-it-yourself-type stuff.  I still find it very soothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy that you're working again.  As long as it comes naturally, that's terrific. You've always liked working with your hands, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, since I was a kid.  I had a woodwork class once when I was... in school that time.  Then I learned a lot more when I was in the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- institution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. (shuffles paper) So, you have a new place, you've started working a bit -- I'm sure you'll be meeting some new people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I have met someone. There's a woman I think I like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, good -- well, I hope you'll have more to tell me next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A twelve-year-old boy, NEIL DREYER, rushes up the steps t the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider watches through the vent as Neil runs around th attic in a circle then runs out again.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Neil runs down the stairs and past Julie, who's with the Real-Estate Lady, and past --

dialogues.speaker: PHIL DREYER
dialogues.text: Husband and father, who turns around as Neil zooms past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, don't leave the back doors open -- I don't want Holly near the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd have to get one of those sliding covers for the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Real-Estate Lady glances with a smile at HOLLY DREYER five years old, wandering around in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- they're quite inexpensive and easy to install.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking Julie aside, to Real-Estate Lady) Do you mind if we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- take as much time as you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Real-Estate Lady goes to be with Holly while Phil lea Julie into the living room.  On the way, Julie happens to notice that the creaking floorboard doesn't anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Phil paces around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie, I just don't think we can afford this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOOM to an air-conditioning vent in a wall behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider is listening on an intercom he's obviously set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouths the word to himself) ... "Julie"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie remains still and calm as she watches her husband walk nervously around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear what you're saying, but I know what you're thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're thinking exactly what I thought when I first saw this house,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This -- is -- the -- one -- for -- us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop knowing me so well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's at the high end of our range --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High end?  Honey, it's a whole new budget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's what we want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted furniture too, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't expect to get what they're asking.  Let's make an offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to bargain at the high end of our range?  -- I'll have a stroke.  I've got to save all my sweat for my meeting in three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have a pool to cool off in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks out at pool, nodding) It's a nice pool, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's a shorter commute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be even shorter if I get that new job.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil takes her hand and walk out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil kneels by the pool, splashing his hand in the water.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE AND PHIL
dialogues.text: Standing back further in the garden, regarding the house from this viewpoint.  Little Holly plays on the grass nea them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do it.  Take a breath and -- and if we're over our heads, well, we'll sell it.  Philip, this is our house.  You know it is.  It's our house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is nodding to himself now, her enthusiasm turning hi on.  Finally he gives in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, but look, we can't say anything to this shark lady now, okay?  We have to play it real cool.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SIDE OF FENCE
dialogues.text: The Nasty Neighbor, watering his yard, notices them, particularly Julie, and stares.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE AND PHIL
dialogues.text: Starting back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if someone else buys it in the meantime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, nobody buys a house overnight -- if someone else comes back at them, well, we might have to make a counter offer.  But we can't look too eager or we'll get screwed.

dialogues.speaker: THE POOL
dialogues.text: The Real-Estate Lady stands by Neil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you've seen a lot of houses then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a bunch, but my mom really likes this one.  She was all excited when she saw it and got my dad all excited when she told him about it.  He's sick of looking already.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE AND PHIL
dialogues.text: Strolling back, trying to look cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we gonna buy this house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have enough money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Real-Estate Lady) We're going to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very nice, but it's still a little pricey for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go back inside) Well, Mr. Dreyer, I don't have to tell you what an important investment a house is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I never recommend property to my clients as merely a good investment.  There are bonds that can serve just as well. A house for me is a place I want to live and raise my family in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something shiny on the floor.  We HEAR them COMIN BACK in.  Holly appears, notices the shiny thing, comes t pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly comes running out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy, Mommy, Mommy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie sweeps her daughter up in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I found a cent!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Find a penny, pick it up, all day long you'll have good luck!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straining to hear the SOFTLY CRACKLING VOICES on his intercom, he's thrilled that she got the point and shares common folklore with him.  He goes "Yeah!" to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly shows the Real-Estate Lady the penny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at my coin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a good omen, sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if on cue, some birds alight on a sunny windowsill nearby and start chirping.  Julie is delighted, turning Holly to show her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: tugs his father's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, we can't decide unless Rudolf gets to look too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Real-Estate Lady) Would you mind if Rudolf had a look too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By all means, let's Rudolf's opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil flings open the front door -- and Rudolf comes charging in -- barking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider's eyes go wide in alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudolf races right up the stairs!

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Rudolf rushes toward the attic doorway, his paws sliding on the new floor.  He barks.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Phil shouts upstairs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudolf, get down here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOOF-WOOF!  Rudolf reappears. comes charging downstairs, goes running right through the house and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stupid dog runs right outside and jumps straight in t pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, gross!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay -- Rudolf likes the house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, c'mon now, get him out of there!  -- This isn't our house yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is leaving. Phil whispering an aside to Julie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How were we -- were we cool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Newman in "The Hustler."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good -- that's what I was trying to project.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: takes a last look over her shoulder, noticing more birds at another window.  A lyrical scene that charms her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying looking out his vent at her, the Hider bites his ha with glee. CAMERA PANS BACK from him to his shelf... where sits a packet of bird seed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider, walking by again, sees that a "SOLD" sticker h been plastered onto the "FOR SALE" sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider is looking at telephones.  He chooses one to bu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider is in the house.  Doing something at a telephon jack.  Then we SEE him unreeling a length of wire into th closet, and we HEAR a DRILL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's run a wire up here and is now connecting it to the phone he bought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the Hider is relaxing on his mattress, his phone to h ear.  His call is answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dial Answer Service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, this is Tom Sykes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sykes?  Let me see... there were two calls for you today.  One from Dr. Levine at three o'clock -- he'd like to reschedule next week's appointment, if possible. And the dry cleaners called and said your jacket is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I forgot about that. I've been real busy.  I just got a new phone installed, so I thought I'd test it.  Okay, Claire, thanks a lot, talk to you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr. Sykes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider disconnects his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's DRILLING again.  Stopping, he blows away the dust an presses his face down to the tiny hole he's made, squinti to see if he can see anything through it.  He sits up again, wiping his brow,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asleep.  Breeze enters through the outside wall vent rustling his hair.  He's awakened by the SOUND of a CAR parking in the driveway.  He rolls over and pulls the lev of his vent for a view outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil gets out of his car, smiling, holding his hand out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, honey -- let's go play in the new house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all excited to see Julie again -- but then his face drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another woman has emerged from the car, taking Phil's han as he leads her to the front door.  A very attractive, toothy young woman.  His SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come in.  The Secretary looking around.  She has a certain air of sophistication that makes Phil want to swoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, I like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil starts hugging her. They both giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this -- is the master bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?  Where's the bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is still completely empty, but he goes and outlines where the bed will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a king or a queen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a double.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to nibble her neck) Even cosier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- you got the bill this morning.  I put it on your desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you -- how efficient of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is to the floor, looking through the peephole he made.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE PEEPHOLE
dialogues.text: He sees the two of them dropping to the floor, Phil's han going up under his Secretary's skirt, helping her tug dow her pantyhose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He recoils.  He's disgusted by this.  But more than that, he's angry -- angry for Julie.  She's married to this bastard.  The Hider gets more and more incensed as he thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is on his feet again, buckling his pants.  His Secretary is pulling her pantyhose back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and his Secretary on their way out, Phil pausing to punch in the code on the security box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we move in, everyone's going to have to learn to work this complicated security system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and his Secretary come out.  Phil double-locks the front door, proudly showing his Secretary the key to his new house.  His face flushed with contentment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider watches them leave.  His face flushed with ange and hatred.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Moving day as the Dreyers move into their new house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are boxes and things in the entrance hall, and VOIC coming from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family cheers as a clear picture appears on a big col TV and Phil emerges from behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay!  We have TV!  We can all get stupid again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about cable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get cable when the cable company is good and ready -- you think you can survive till then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme a break, Neil -- your father just spent three hours connecting the VCR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil pushes a button to play a tape -- and we SEE Steve McQueen in solitary confinement in "Papillion" or "The Great Escape."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, that's enough for one day -- I want everyone up at the crack of dawn.  We have the whole weekend to get this place in shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone moans, too excited to go to bed, as he turns off the VCR and the TV and everyone upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dumps out of a box more cars, guns, soldiers and robot than we've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil looks out the window over his new street before hanging up a sheet as a temporary curtain.  It falls down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie sits on the bed, reading Holly a bedtime story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '"... or I'll huff and I'll puff and I'll blow your house down!" And inside their new house, the three little pigs just laughed -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Who's afraid of the Big Bad Wolf, the Big Bad Wolf...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudolf the dog sniffs at the closed attic door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "FOR SALE" sign is gone, of course.  The Dreyers' two cars are in the driveway.  There are lights on in the house.  One by one they go out.  And then... up in what seems to be the attic... a single light... comes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider is at a perfume counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you being helped, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for some perfume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any particular brand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's for a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, although the Hider wasn't being humorous) Wife, girlfriend or mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- uh -- girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie turns to her kids, who are finishing breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, kids, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) "We don't want to be late for our first day of school."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking in refrigerator) All right, who ate the last piece of cheesecake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jabs his little sister in the ribs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Neil.  Stop teasing your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slams refrigerator door) Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly turns her head, deadpan, as she watches her Dad wal out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil walks from the house toward his car -- when he sees the Nasty Neighbor kick a paper cup from his drive onto Phil's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- uh, excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes over.  The Nasty Neighbor turns around and stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I didn't kick this onto your property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil tosses it into a nearby brand-new garbage can on his side of their common border.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; holds out his hand) Phil Dreyer -- we just moved in over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nasty Neighbor stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you have kids -- and a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep 'em quiet and away from my property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away, muttering something under his breath.  Phi is stunned by this impoliteness -- as Julie comes out wit the kids and the dog, ushering them into her car, then coming over to Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear what he said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made, you know, a remark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And keep my kids away from his property -- who the hell does he think he is?  Some nice neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, the meeting today is going to be fine.  Don't get in an uproar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  It's just having to pass muster with these juniors before the senior partner even agrees to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a dumb game they play. You want to be at a bigger firm, get used to the politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in b.g.) MOM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie gives Phil a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VIEW DOWN on the driveway from, say, the attic of the house.  We SEE Phil give Julie a perfunctory kiss.  He waves to the kids as he goes to his car but first turns to the garbage can, picks out the paper cup, and tosses i over the Nasty Neighbor's fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She parks the car -- and turns to Neil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, kid,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil doesn't find that particular amusing.  He looks with a frown at where they've arrived -- his new school.  He reluctantly gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hey. (leans for a kiss) Have a nice time -- it's a good school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Neil!

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: As Julie drives away, he turns around to see -- -- a terrifying, brutish kid staring malevolently at him and making kissing sounds.  This is the BULLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking sarcastically) "Bye, Mom -- Bye, Mommy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bully has two Goons flanking him, also making kissing noises, and giggling at Neil's expense. Neil just thinks to himself, "Oh, Christ."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in the house now, the Hider descends from the attic coming cautiously out of the attic doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider, listening for sounds from the driveway outside pulls a shirt of Phil's from a laundry basket.  He starts pouring perfume on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie takes Holly inside with other small children and their parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil leans against a wall, frown on his face, hands in hi pockets.  Watching a game of kickball he hasn't been invited to join in.  Suddenly, the Bully and his Goons ar standing in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Neil.  How's it goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Bernard, by the way.  Those are cool Reeboks, Neil.  They're real new, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bully scuffs Neil's new Reeboks with his own shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, c'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're really white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bully's two Goons join in, all smearing their shoes o Neil's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, c'mon, you guys, lay off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to move forward, but the Bully pushes him back against the wall and holds him there while the two Goons continue messing up Neil's shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta break 'em in for you. You don't wanna go 'round lookin' like a new dil-wad, do ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to something on Neil's shirt.  Neil looks down and the Bully slaps his face.  The Bully walks away, givi Neil a shove.  His Goons do the same.  Presently, two FRIENDLY BOYS come up to Neil (one is the boy who lives next door to Neil).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You met Bernard.  Nice guy, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie's car comes back.  She gets out with the dog.  She' juggling two bags of groceries.  She drops one of them an after bending over to pick it up hears a NOISE, turns to see the Nasty Neighbor leering at her.  She goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Putting the bags down, Julie peeks past the blind at the window next to the door, watching the Nasty Neighbor go back to his house.  She sees the Nasty Neighbor's Wife there, giving the Nasty Neighbor a hard time.  The Nasty Neighbor ignores his wife, walking past her into their house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is putting laundry into the washer.  We HEAR a SMAL NOISE in the house that she doesn't seem to notice.  She sorts out some clothes.  Then pauses, pilling out a shirt of her husband's.  She holds the collar up to her nose. Something bothers her.  She smells the collar again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider looks pensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, things are moving along, but she's still involved with this other guy and it's a little tricky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, no one ever said expressing yourself to the opposite sex is easy, but when the time comes, you have to do it and you hope the outcome will be good for both of you. You come out of solitary and you rejoin the human race, as difficult as that sometimes can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a child... I got used to the closets.  The boxes.  The cabinet under the kitchen sink... with that persistent drip.  I used to the smell of the boxes. Wood.  Cardboard.  I got so I was comfortable there in the dark. Even... even that old refrigerator in the yard.  That smelled like rust and decay. (pause) It was safe in the boxes.  It was when they took me out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to know what his parents did to him when they took him out of the boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the institution... when you were violent... did you want them to put you in solitary confinement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches the Hider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.  I mean, I know I'm responsible for my own actions. It was never because I was angry with anyone.  I didn't mean to hurt anyone ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're responsible for your own actions and you don't mean to hurt anyone.  In other words, you've done your best.  I'm saying don't carry the burden of other people's actions on your shoulders, because they're beyond your control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider nods in agreement.  There's a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; softer) Are you still afraid of your parents?  Of them finding you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider shifts uncomfortably in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was years and years ago. They must be very old now, if they're still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts on a brave face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) No, my parents don't worry me anymore.  I mean, that's why I was ultimately released, wasn't it? I mean, even with the state closing down the hospital and all. Because I'm able to be on my own at last. (smiles) I'm cured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family life.  Holly is playing with toys in the living ro with the dog.  Neil trails after his mother, who's moving back and forth from the kitchen to the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you just drive me to my old school every morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you'd have to get up at five a.m., would you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could take a cab on the way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, take this out to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's this psycho.  Really. Mom, there's a psycho I have to deal with every day.  I don't know why they let a psycho even go to school!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes him out of the room.  She looks at Phil, who's tossing a salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was your lunch with Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, did he hear anything about your prospects for the new job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  If I hear anything you'll be the first to know, all right?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: watches him take the salad out to the dining room.  We HE HIS VOICE from out there, saying the typical kind of thin a parent says in a child-filled house when he's trying to clear the table for dinner:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose is this?  Who left this here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fast asleep.  So is the dog on the floor.  A mask of a bearded man hangs from a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fast asleep.  A Disney mobile twirls gently in the air overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie and Phil fast asleep.  She's turned toward him.  He turned away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog scratches again at the attic door... which slowly starts to open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Sunday-lunch housewarming party is in progress.  Julie is greeting Phil's friend, CHARLIE, who's just arrived wi his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing over a present) -- A little something for the new house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other guests are in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some cute teenage girls in bikinis are lounging around th pool.  They're giggling as they pass a cigarette of some kind between them, checking over their shoulders that the are no adults around.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BACK OF THE GARDEN
dialogues.text: Neil and his two Friends from his new school are spying o the girls.  Behind them, a rope ladder dangles from a treehouse under construction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, your sister's really hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at her.  Look at the other ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests are eating now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the neighbors are a little weird -- other than that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another couple, the Nice Neighbors, laugh at that.  (The woman is the mother next door who the Hider saw come home that day.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Present company excepted -- it's the neighbors out there to the right who are a bit strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I caught him looking at me the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In all the years we've lived here, I don't think we've spoken a word to them, have we, hon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes when I go to the hospital early in the morning, I've seen him coming home.  Maybe he works at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll probably see the wife once in a while at the supermarket. Truly one of the walking dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More easy laughter.  A very sensual woman, RITA, smokes a cigarette and gives Julie a wink.  Julie smiles back. Clearly they're best friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like your normal upper- middle-class neighborhood to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls go away.  The boys emerge from their hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's follow 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for, dickweed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grow up, Dreyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is making coffee in here with Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done a really great job with the house.  It's great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  There's still a lot I want to do.  It's not quite... the kids aren't really settled in yet. Even the dog has been terribly high-strung and whines a lot since we've been here.  Look, he hasn't even come in for his food today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't have anything concrete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I told you.  A whiff of perfume on his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you just plain asked him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've asked him what's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same thing -- his business pressures, the whole move and everything.  He's frantic about nailing this new job, worried about screwing over his present boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that's all it is, honey. Maybe you both just need a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tried to get him to agree to one.  I just -- I don't know... I'm getting such weird vibes lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't drive yourself crazy.  It's probably nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys come in from the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; flirting shamelessly) Hi, Neil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  We're going to the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and his friends go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita, he's only twelve years old,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising her drink) He'll never appreciate it more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie lifts Holly up into her lap, then engrossed in conversation doesn't pay attention when Holly climbs back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... No, not really.  We do hear of break-ins now and again, but it's generally a real low-crime area.  We've never had any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any kind of Neighborhood Watch or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts arm around his wife) You're talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife laughs and gives him a playful slap on the arm. Phil seems to be flirting with Rita.  Holly walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly comes out from the room. She starts along toward... the door out to the pool that's been left wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly comes out.  She walks to the pool.  She walks to th edge and looks over the water, walks further on -- toward the deep end.  She crouches the there.  She picks up a leaf and tosses it in the pool and watches it float.  She reaches to bring it back but it's already floated too far out.  She reaches further, leaning over t deep water and -- SUDDENLY two big hands lunge at her bac -- as if to push her in -- but they grab her to stop her falling in, and lift her up in the air, running back to t house with her, pushing her inside and shutting the door with a definite CLICK behind her,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie and Phil are cleaning up after their housewarming. Julie is looking at a very pretty green vase among other presents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember who gave us this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no card or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie and Phil in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear things in this house,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All new houses have noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does it have to be a new house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day before we know it it'll be an old house and we'll be old in it -- and I'll still be paying for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil's still having a bad time at school.  I feel terrible seeing him so upset all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's made some friends, hasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is starting to give Phil little nibbles on his neck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I mean, he's a smart kid, he'll get by -- he takes after me. You're too sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seductively) I know someone else who's sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's rubbing him under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (had enough of this) Honey, I have a lot of meetings in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You never know when, do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wakes up.  He's restless.  He's hot.  He reaches for o of his water bottles, but it's empty.  He licks his lips. Now that he's thought about having a drink, he can't get the idea out of his mind.  He lies down again, but soon sits up.  He's starting to feel a little trapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider emerges out of his secret panel in the floor. He's holding an water bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door from the attic stairway slowly opens.  The Hider carefully steps out.  He looks one way -- all clear -- looks the other -- and stops dead in his tracks. Holly is standing at the other end of the hall looking at him.  She rubs her eyes sleepily.  When she looks again, the Hider is gone. Holly turns around and walks to her parents' door where s knocks. Julie opens the door, looking down at Holly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to lead Holly down the main stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's back in hiding, and hitting himself for his carelessness, sweating more than ever, desperately afraid that he almost blew the whole deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie holds Holly's hand as they descend the dark stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the middle of the night, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man scared me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man?  Was it a dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family have breakfast.  Phil reads the "Wall Street Journal," not even looking at his toast as he lifts it to his mouth.  Julie feels ignored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) Has anyone seen Rudolf?  I don't think he came in last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey, I haven't seen him. Didn't you feed him this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams) RUDOLF!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softer) Rudolf?  C'mere, Rudolf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly is drawing a picture.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY'S PICTURE
dialogues.text: A dark silhouette of a man's shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudolf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil cradles Holly on the couch.  She's crying.  The fami watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry, honey, Rudolf knows how to take care of himself.  I'm sure he's okay.  Maybe he just went on a trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like our vacation?  Are we still going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil looks at Julie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess it would be good for us to get away for a while.  Maybe Rudolf got the same idea.  Dogs need a change of scene, too, from time to time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strokes Holly's hair) Someone nice will find him if he gets lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it here!  I hate it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs out and upstairs.  Julie and Phil look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider sits at the counter, eating a simple meal.  It' late.  There are a few other lonely people at the counter or in booths.  A faded WAITRESS.  It's an American scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flirting slightly) You didn't finish your greens, but I'll let you have some dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up check) No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you know you want some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not tonight, I have to be getting on home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves enough money on the counter and turns away.  Th Waitress's hopes go with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider, like the human fly, crawls up the side of the house using his toeholds, shielded by the vines and shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil is walking away from his dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then, if I have to go to school then I'd better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  I just read your report card.  What's the point?  Stay home, watch some television, we'll get "Mad" magazine delivered. (waves report card) What kind of report card do you call this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been going through a lot of personal crap, all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really?  You've been going through a lot of personal crap. You, Princess Di and Madonna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) If you want that baseball jacket for your birthday, Neil, learn to cough a little more realistically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the thermometer say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thermometer's broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have a temperature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help it if my homework is torn to shreds three times a week by someone much bigger than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know what?  I'm ready to cancel our trip.  I really am. I've had it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I can't help having a cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you want me to do, Neil? I've told you we'll get another dog.  What does EVERYONE want me to do?  You want to move back? Huh?  Would you like that?  Should we all just pack up again and MOVE BACK?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This yell resounds throughout the entire house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil is walking home from school.  He HEARS something and looks back nervously.  Suddenly, the Bully and his Goons come out of some trees, surrounding Neil. Immediately they start shoving him around a bit, taking h bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it here, Bernard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, check it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new fountain-pen set he finds in Neil's bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice pen, Neil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes it at Neil, spraying ink all over the new baseball jacket he's wearing -- then stabs the nib into a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Goons hold Neil back.  The Bully hits Neil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me a fucker, you little asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He yanks a pocket of Neil's jacket until it tears.  Neil tries to get him again but one of the Goons trips him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hey, you're really clumsy, Neil. Look at the mess you made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dumps the rest of the contents of Neil's bag over Neil head and walks away laughing cruelly with his Goons.  Nei looks at his jacket and calls after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCKERS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the Bully is walking home.  Alone.  Suddenly he stops There's a dollar on the ground in front of him.  He bends to pick it up -- and a hand CLAMPS over his face and pull him into some bushes.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BUSHES
dialogues.text: The Bully is dragged deeper in.  He struggles in sheer panic.  He's twisted around momentarily.  His face is filled with fear as he glimpses his attacker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider's big hand muffles him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie flattens the baseball jacket out to have a look wit Neil.  It looks all right.  We HEAR a PHONE RING and PHIL ANSWER it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we got it just in time before the ink dried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pocket's a cinch -- I'll sew it up for you after dinner, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is about to hang up.  Holly sits at the kitchen tabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Oh, gee, well, thanks for letting us know. Goodbye. (there's a double click) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.  Julie and Neil come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh boy, I just heard something horrible.  That was Audrey next door.  Neil, do you know a boy named Bernard Gunther?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil looks up in alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) He lives on the other side of the hill, I guess, so don't get too scared, but it looks like he was just, I don't know, attacked on his way home from school.  Audrey heard that he was... (catches himself with a sigh) ... well, apparently he's in the hospital now.  One of his legs was...  They don't know if he'll ever walk properly again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the silence and dread that follow, no one notices the great big beaming smile of sheer God-given good fortune that breaks out on Neil's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil has a grin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the table from him is his Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the table she's slipped off a shoe and is running h stockinged foot up his thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. the Hider sits at another table alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider takes a book of matches from the ashtray on his table and plays with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil comes upstairs looking for something.  Neil walks by wearing his bearded-man mask and goes downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey!  Was the paper delivered today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is for their trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so!  Didn't you take it in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider isn't here.  But more stuff is.  A cork bulleti board has been put up.  On the bulletin board are all sor of pictures, clippings, bits and pieces.  Things that interest the Hider.  There's a calendar with "VACATION!" marked prominently.  And underneath on his mattress lies the newspaper.  Folded to the movie-listings page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie takes one of Phil's jackets and something falls out of the pocket.  She bends to pick up whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, wearing his bearded-man mask, joins his sister on t couch to watch TV.  She pays no attention to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is trying to look stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old incriminating matchbook! Are you kidding me?!  The oldest cliche in the world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is looking mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not kidding you, Philip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What next?!  -- A strange bra under my pillow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider munches popcorn slowly as he watches a romantic scene.  He's quite swept up by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil tosses the incriminating matchbook onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember what day you wore that jacket.  It was Monday.  The day you were all day in meetings again?  And had to send out for sandwiches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, you know what I've been like lately... I've been a total zombie.  I have no idea what that was doing in my pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what about these? (taking something else out) Do you usually put your carbons in your pocket, too?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her wild card.  She flings them in his face and storms in the adjoining bathroom.  Phil stares at the torn-in-half carbons.  He can't believe it.  Didn't he leave them in t restaurant?  Is he getting absent-minded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie packs more things as Phil comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, this is a very risky time for me right now.  Maybe you don't appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care, Philip.  You want to go chasing Barbara Zelman, go ahead.  Just watch out for those buck teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara Zelman?  I don't believe this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you usually pay for Charlie? At "Trattoria Valentino"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I can't track of all the meals Charlie and I have been having.  This is a delicate time. If it leaks out that I'm jumping ship before I'm set up someplace else I could be out on my ear before I'm ready with nothing. With nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going back to the bedroom) There are people who do things because they want to get caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil comes out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that -- someone on the radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Philip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider strolls along, drinking a soft drink through a straw.  He passes a flower stand and pauses to look at th arrangements.  He turns a reel of seed packets, and pulls one of the packets out to look at.  Just then he hears a NOISE and turns to witness --

dialogues.speaker: A MINOR ACCIDENT
dialogues.text: A car cuts off a bicyclist.  The bicyclist falls off his bike -- scraping his knee quite severely.  Other onlooker go to his aid.  We SEE where his trouser leg was torn and the bloody kneecap.

dialogues.speaker: THE HIDER
dialogues.text: thinks it's funny.  The Hider laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is crying softly in the aftermath of the argument, pouring herself a cup of tea.  Phil is consoling her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we'd be happy here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds her) Honey, I'm sorry, I think the vacation will be a good break for both of us.  You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, taking her tea, and they go out.  Phil shuts th light as they leave -- and we SEE the Hider's face at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacation time.  Phil tries rounding everyone up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab's waiting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where should I hide the car keys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- put 'em in the drawer with all the Chinese take- away menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (goes to do so) Did you lock the garage door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil thinks he's taking along a gigantic plastic Rambo machine gun.  Phil discourages him by grabbing it out of his hands and putting it somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil makes sure the front door is double-locked, then joi the others in the cab. The cab doors SLAM.  The cab drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you set the timer switches for the lights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room in shadow.  Then CLICK -- a lamp comes on. Illuminating the Hider sitting on the couch.  Here in the silent house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whistling, the Hider strolls in, opens a cabinet, takes o a box of Raisin Bran, then finds a bowl for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider watches a sporting event on TELEVISION, keeping the SOUND LOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider plays with Neil's train set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider peers through the skylight.  We HEAR the SOUND of a VACUUM CLEANER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Cleaning Woman goes through the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail has been neatly put on the table.  Out in the entran hall, we SEE the Cleaning Woman leave, locking the front door after her.  The Hider steps INTO VIEW from the kitchen.  He sits at the table to go through the mail.  H opens a letter that's addressed to "OCCUPANT."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plants some flower seeds using a gardening trowel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider has a bath.  He smells a bar of soap,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider gets into the bed.  He strokes her pillow.  He smells it.  He puts his head gently on it.  He's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hider looks quite content today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how are things with your lady friend, if I may call her that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fine.  She's gone away for a little while and when she comes back I've sort of resolved to really tell her how much I care for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's terrific.  Don't be afraid to be demonstrative.  You're sounding a lot more confident than when we last spoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.  I'm really feeling pretty good.  I have a much stronger sense of how far I've come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you keep remembering why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we talked about the whole disapproval thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) The whole disapproval thing.  If you allow yourself to get into a situation where someone else's potential disapproval becomes the focal point of your life -- then you're back to a life of fear, aren't you?  -- You're a prisoner to that again, and that isn't much of a life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And please, don't for God's sake misinterpret that as being the voice of discouragement in any way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary -- this is tremendous.  I mean, we're all frightened to death of disapproval and we're constantly hiding behind these layers we manufacture for ourselves -- and I'm not saying we should, you know, declare ourselves unhesitatingly to our fellow human beings in the interests of total openness and honesty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be monumentally stupid. All I'm saying is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a sense of proportion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods emphatically) A sense of proportion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SCRATCHING at the glass.  Then a TAP.  And a CLINK.  An a CLICK.  And the curtain stirs -- and a Burglar slips in He crouches by the floor a moment, listening and getting accustomed to the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Burglar opens the drawers of some cabinets in here. Looking for loot.  It's after midnight and the lights are out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Burglar comes in.  He goes over to the TV and crouche down to look at the VCR in the trolley underneath.  He ru his hand over its smooth surface, then suddenly leans forward to unscrew cables at the back.  This abrupt movement probably extends his life by a few minutes -- because when a hammer comes down on his head, the blow is only a glancing one. The Burglar groans and turns -- the Hider was thrown off- balance by his miss -- and the Burglar has enough time to put an arm up for protection -- the second blow shatterin his elbow.  He cries out in pain, but he's a strong man himself.  He's a match for the Hider!  He manages to grab the Hider's ankle at the same time and pull him completel off-balance -- the Hider throwing his arm out to stop himself falling, knocking to the floor the vase he bought for Julie -- landing on the floor himself as it SMASHES alongside him -- and with a great gasp the Burglar pushes the big television off the trolley onto the Hider. The Hider has the wind knocked out of him as the big TV lands heavily onto his chest, nearly squashing him like a bug.  The Burglar is already running away, clutching his broken elbow -- but the Hider's powerful arm shoots out t catch his leg, pulling the Burglar back, while with an almost superhuman effort the Hider heaves the TV off his chest. The Burglar struggles with all his might.  The two men wrestle on the living room floor.  The Burglar tries to gouge out the Hider's eyes.  Craning his face out of the reach of the Burglar's flailing, frenzied fingers, the Hider tries to get a firm grasp on him.  He grabs wildly at the Burglar's hair, finally getting a good hold.  He smashes the Burglar's head onto the glass-topped coffee table.  BANG, BANG, BANG -- the glass cracks -- BANG, BAN BANG, the Burglar's face into the glass until the glass breaks completely. The Burglar won't give up.  He's beyond pain.  He's only trying to survive.  His hand is at the Hider's throat, squeezing.  They throttle each ether.  The Burglar is on his back, his legs kicking at the Hider.  His shoe catche the Hider a kick to the ear.  They both cough and gasp as a release is forced, both struggling for a better positio the Burglar trying to slide out from under again, the Hid keeping him down -- and now the Hider is able to seize th Burglar's arm again and jam the fingers in a door jamb an pull the door back.  We don't hear the Burglar scream because the Hider's other hand is in his mouth, but the Burglar bites down so hard on it the Hider is the one who lets out a roar of animal agony and the Burglar's good ha punches at his face, the Burglar somehow on his feet agai trying to make it to the dining room. The Hider catches hold of the Burglar's shirt, tearing it but pulling the Burglar back to the floor -- and the Hider's foot slips in some blood and he lands hard on his back, hitting his head, the Burglar's torn shirt in his hand.  The Burglar is crawling on all fours to get away, but his knees slip in the blood, too, and the Hider's leg grapple him like a pair of pythons, pulling him back, and the two of them struggle on the slippery floor, out of breath, near exhaustion.
